At-a-Glance: Thymol products need warmth and good brood nest airflow. Dose steadily; avoid honey taint period on market supers.
Why it Matters: Lower risk when used within temperature band.
Objectives: Keep supers for sale off during treatment.
What Good Looks Like: Steady release over full course duration.
Bees can ventilate; entrances not overly reduced.
Step-by-Step: 1) Check forecast; confirm band (often warm, not hot).
2) Place trays/gel per instructions; avoid spill.
4) Verify reduction; wait taint interval before supering.
Seasonality & Climate: Shoulder seasons ideal; too cool reduces release.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Low effect -> Too cool or short course; adjust next round.
Tools & Techniques: Thymol trays/gels, timer reminders, sampling kit.
Safety & Compliance: Follow label and food taint guidance.
Field Checklist: Temp band OK; supers off for market honey.
Communications: Explain taint intervals to the team clearly.
Notes: Write the re-dose date on the crownboard with a wipeable pen.
